Package fr.ens.biologie.generic

Interface Initialisable

public interface Initialisable

An interface for objects that require initialisation (whatever this means) after instantiation.

In big applications, the initialisation of objects is often a complex procedure where many different classes must be instantiated in a precise order, and sometimes with reciprocal dependencies that impose some more initialisation after instantiation. This interface defines two methods that help this process:

  • initialise() performs all the operations required before any instance of this interface can be considered 'ready'.
  • initRank() returns a rank that insures that the initialisations are made in the proper order.

This interface is meant to be used with the Initialiser class. Initialiser is constructed with a list of Initialisable instances. Then, a call to Initialiser.initialise() will call the initialise() method of all Initialisable instances in turn, in order of increasing initRank().

Author:
Jacques Gignoux - 7 mai 2019

  • Method Summary

    Modifier and Type
    Method
    Description
    void
    initialise()
    Initialises this instance after construction.
    int
    initRank()
    This is used to decide in which order objects must be initialised.

  • Method Details

    • initialise

      void initialise() throws Exception
      Initialises this instance after construction. Often, classes require other classes to be initialized before they themselves can proceed. These associated classes will be initialized at the first attempt by a class to use them. Thus, initialization occurs in a cascading chain.
      Throws:
      Exception - If initialization fails or one its associated classes in the cascading chain fails to initialize.

    • initRank

      int initRank()
      This is used to decide in which order objects must be initialised. They will be initialised from the lowest to the highest priority. The use case is to set this as a class constant.
      Returns:
      the priority level for the object to initialise.
